text: The effectiveness of personally tailored computer- generated advice letters for smoking cessation
Aim To assess the effectiveness of anew computer-generated tailored advice programme designed to be used by smokers and recent quitters having problems staying stopped.

Design Randomized trial comparing a series of questionnaire assessments leading to tailored computer-generated advice letters mailed at strategically relevant times, to a no extra treatment control sent standardized printed self-help materials.
Participants A total of 1058 smokers or recent quitters recruited from callers to the Quitline.
Measurements Smoking status and sustained abstinence at 12 - month follow-up, plus extent of participation in the intervention.

Findings Using a conservative analysis (missing data coded as a treatment failure), 6 - month sustained abstinence was reported by significantly more participants in the computer-generated tailored advice (20%) than the standard printed materials condition (12%) at 12 - month follow-up OR 1.82 (1.31 - 2.55)).
Group differences in point prevalence abstinence (28% intervention, 25% control) were not significant.
Among participants in the tailored advice condition, 6 - month sustained abstinence was associated with the number of advice letters received.
Conclusion The provision of a series of tailored, computer-generated advice letters resulted in greater rates of sustained cessation than for controls.
A dose-response relationship was found, with increased compliance with the intervention associated with improved cessation outcomes.
The programme appears to have much of its effect by preventing relapse.

Services to smokers can range from mass media campaigns with broadly directed encouragement to quit, through provision of printed self-help materials, to intensive group or individual-based cessation therapies.

As the intensity of these services increases, so does their effectiveness), yet at some point interventions are likely to become too expensive and/or demanding on potential users to be widely disseminated.
Computer-tailoring of advice can go someway towards providing the personalization of intensive counselling, but at low cost.

Ina review of 13 randomized trials that assessed the effectiveness of tailored printed materials for smoking cessation, concluded that tailored materials were more effective than standard self-help manuals [10 trials, odds ratio 1.36 (1.13 - 1.64)] or no materials [three trials, odds ratio 1.80 (1.46 - 2.23)].
Research has begun to examine factors that influence the effectiveness of tailored materials for smoking cessation.
Tailoring advice to stage of change and other aspects of the transtheoretical model (TTM) of behaviour change) has been shown to be effective ().
The evidence for beneficial effects of multiple contacts with smokers is less clear.) have shown a beneficial effect of multiple contacts but did not.
Recently we found no beneficial effects of a tailoring programme based on the TTM () among callers to a Quitline telephone advice service.

In that paper we speculated that the failure to find effects occurred because the TTM programme is most useful for guiding smokers towards quitting, and is not well suited to helping them beyond that point.
Due to the nature of recruitment, our sample was almost universally interested in quitting at the time the programme began.
The advice they received focused on motivating a quit attempt and initiating appropriate planning.
It provided no advice on how to cope once quit until the next assessment (at 3 months), if they were still quit at that point.
Not only do there appear to be complications with the scheduling of advice, the TTM stages are also problematic, at least when used as a basis for communicating with potential quitters.

For example, the TTM definition of preparation requires that smokers have made a failed quit attempt in the previous year, creating the apparently contradictory situation of some people who say they are planning to quit being told they are not quite ready.
In our view, the cognitive and behavioural aspects of stages need to be separated, at least when used as the basis for communication.
Another example is the presumption that precontemplators are uniformly not interested in quitting.
However, there exists a significant group of precontemplators who are not interested in quitting (at present) because they seethe task as too difficult.

For them, advice needs to be around enhancing self-efficacy and building skills, while for the other group of precontemplators the focus is probably more on motivation, along the lines suggested by the TTM.
We divide precontemplators into those who are not contemplating quitting because they want to continue smoking (at least in part), and those who believe it is too difficult to quit.
These groups differ in that the latter group does not need to be convinced of the value of quitting, but of the possibility of success.
These two groups are treated similarly to contemplators in our programme, as we assume that anyone prepared to engage with the programme is at least open to contemplating quitting.

Preparers (planning to quit in the next 30 days) are subdivided into those who have set a quit date and those who have not, as this is a major step toward action, and one around which advice needs to be provided.
The post quitting stages of the TTM have been singled out for their arbitrariness.
Research suggests that nicotine withdrawal symptoms are experienced typically for 1 - 2 weeks after quitting, with the most difficult period being within the first week.
Beyond this the frequency of strong urges to smoke declines, albeit at a different rate for each individual.
As this occurs, the quitter often feels as if they have succeeded.
Self-efficacy at this point predicts outcomes negatively, suggesting a danger of overconfidence.
The task at this point is more about learning to think and act like a non-smoker and to feel comfortable in the new role.
In order to differentiate these distinctions from the TTM stages and to show their importance for communication, we describe these groupings as perspectives on change.

In this study, we refer to six main perspectives: (a) disengaged-precontemplators and contemplators from the TTM; (b) engaged-planning to quit in the next 30 days, without a quit date in the next 14 days; (c) committed-having a quit date within the next 14 days; (d) implementation-first week of quit attempt, or up to 2 weeks if cravings are described as continual; (e) consolidation-from end of implementation till strong urges to smoke occur less than daily or concurrent use of NRT; (f) synthesis-less than daily strong urges to smoke and no use of NRT.
An additional problem with the TTM is that it fails to consider characteristics of the individual and of the environment or context (except via their beliefs).
These characteristics are important when tailoring information, as they can alter the nature of the task and/or probable motivating factors.
For example, considering age and the presence of any smoking-related health problems can allow the issue of health to be framed in a maximally useful way.

entities.text: presence of any smoking-related health problems can allow the issue of health to be framed

text: Similarly, level of addiction is likely to be important.

The aim of this research was to compare the impact of standardized Australian printed self-help cessation materials (as a control condition) with anew tailored computer-generated advice programme (the Steps to Stop Program) developed to deliver tailored advice sensitive to the issues discussed above.
In our view, if tailored advice can be made more relevant and timely it is likely to be more effective.
Participants were recruited from callers to the Victorian Quitline, a community service providing information and advice on all aspects of smoking cessation, between April and August 2000.
A total of 1351 callers agreed to be recontacted for research during their initial call.

Callers interested in quitting receive printed self-help materials routinely (a 'Quit pack'), which consists of a 30 - page fullcolour A5 'Quit Because You Can' booklet organized around stages of change; a leaflet which promotes the Quitline callback service and group-based 'Fresh Start' smoking cessation courses; and a business-sized card that describes strategies to resist cravings.
Eligible callers were adult cigarette smokers or recent quitters who requested written materials only-callers who sought personal advice were not eligible for the study.
Participants also had to be able to communicate in English, and have no obvious psychiatric or neurological problems.
Recent quitters had to report at least daily strong urges to smoke.
The final sample of 1058 smokers or recent exsmokers included 490 males and 568 females, with mean age 32.3 years (SD 10.7).
Sample size was based on power to detect a 5% absolute difference in quit rates between the two groups.
The questions asked were in part tailored to individuals' perspective on change, except where data were required from all respondents.

The CATI questionnaire assessed three components: first, only at baseline, basic demographic information (age, gender, eligibility for the , and quitting history (ever tried to quit before, time since longest quit attempt, duration of longest attempt).
A quit attempt was defined as abstinence from smoking for greater than 24 hours.

We also assessed the participant's social context (household composition, presence of smoking bans at home and at work, proportion of smokers among those they socialize with regularly, social support to quit) and the presence of a health condition or other problem that may affect their chances of quitting.
The core section that was asked at each assessment elicited information for allocating the respondent to a perspective on change, with subsequent questions varying by perspective.

All participants were asked whether there were any quit attempts since last assessment, duration of last quit attempt, and for those who had quit (i.e. those who reported smoking less often than weekly or not at all), length of time quit, any recent slip-ups and any weight change.
Current smokers (those who reported smoking daily or less often than weekly) were also asked about usual daily cigarette consumption and time to first cigarette of the day.
Both smokers and quitters were asked about current use of nicotine replacement products for cessation (gum, patches or inhaler); and use of other assistance to quit.
This section also included single-item measures of self-efficacy, determination to quit, frequency and strength of temptations to smoke and four items on rated positive and negative affect.
The questionnaire for the control group and for research-only assessments ended here, as subsequent questions were primarily used for tailoring advice.

The third section assessed the pros and cons of smoking, self-efficacy to quit smoking and to become a permanent non-smoker; strength of temptations to smoke across a range of positive, negative and habitual situations; use of change processes; and questions about residual smoking experiences and beliefs (this last set asked only of those in the consolidation and synthesis perspectives).
The intervention was a series of assessments each followed by a mailed tailored letter.
The respondent was phoned and asked the assessment questions, which were entered into the computer programme that generated the tailored advice.
No counselling was provided over the phone.
A typical advice letter consisted of two to three pages of text, divided into approximately six to eight separate paragraphs.

The tailored letters were organized around the above-mentioned perspectives on change, with an introductory paragraph outlining cognitive and behavioural tasks required for progress to the next perspective.

Subsequent paragraphs provided advice tailored to past quitting history, level of addiction, need for concurrent use of NRT and/or other professional advice, recent emotional state and (for recent quitters) frequency of urges to smoke and the occurrence of recent slip-ups.
The letters also encouraged positive cessation-related thoughts and discouraged negative ones.
Some paragraphs were also tailored on age and gender, to enhance the personalized feel of the letters and include material relevant to subgroups defined by these two variables.
Timing of reassessments differed according to the individual's perspective on change.
The Steps to Stop Program computed a follow-up date automatically at the end of each assessment, which was then checked with the participant for convenience.
The reassessment schedule was designed to provide more frequent assessments clustered around a quit attempt.
Therefore, the number of letters each individual could receive varied considerably, according to their pattern of perspective change and the frequency of making a quit attempt.
Appendix I provides detail of the reassessment schedule.
Subsequent advice letters were sensitive to the occurrence of perspective change between assessments, giving recipients a sense of the programme tracking their progress.

Enclosed with the first tailored letter was general information about the Steps to Stop Program, including a brief explanation of the ideas behind the programme and answers to commonly asked questions.

Where appropriate, non-tailored information sheets were included with the tailored advice entitled 'Understanding Your Smoking', 'Strategies for Stopping', 'Implementing Home Bans', 'Dealing With Nicotine Withdrawal', 'Getting Through The Early Days' and 'Becoming a Non-Smoker'.
The study was approved by the Institutional Ethics Committee of The Cancer Council Victoria.

This included agreement that randomization would occur after agreement to participate in the study, and that participants in each condition would not know about the other condition unless they specifically asked about differences in what participants were given (none did).
Potential participants were contacted soon after their call to the Quitline, typically within 2 days.
They were invited to participate in a study that aimed to investigate smokers and quitters experiences, and how the help they receive affects their success at quitting.
It was explained that participation would involve answering questions now (or at a suitable other time) and again 3, 6 and 12 months later.

Those who agreed to participate were randomized by computer to intervention (tailored advice) or control group via computer-generated ID numbers, with even numbers allocated to the intervention group.
Those allocated to receive tailored computer-generated advice were then told about the programme and asked whether they would like to receive tailored cessation advice in the mail.

It was explained that they would be contacted a number of times (depending on need) to review their progress, and that after each assessment the computer would generate new advice, relevant to their current situation.
If they consented they were provided with the intervention.
Five hundred and twenty-one participants were randomized to the tailored advice condition, and 537 to the control group.

Those who rejected the offer of tailored advice ( n = 34) were retained in the intervention group for all outcome analyses, and continued to receive followup assessments as consented at 3, 6 and 12 months.
Following randomization, the baseline smoking assessment was administered by a trained telephone interviewer.
The assessment took 10 - 20 minutes to complete, varying as a function of randomization (control group questionnaires were shorter) and perspective on change.
Research-only assessments were conducted 3, 6 and 12 months after recruitment.
However, significantly lower response rates in the intervention group at 3 and 6 months (both P < 0.001) meant that these data were not useable for comparisons.

This was caused by some of the intervention group participants who withdrew from treatment (but not from the trial) agreeing to be recontacted fora briefer assessment only at 12 months post recruitment, and not for intermediate assessments.
Three hundred and sixteen participants were lost to follow-up at 12 months, giving an overall retention rate of 70%.

There was a trend for greater dropout in the intervention group (72.8% cf. 67.4%), that approached significance ( c 2 (1) = 3.74, P = 0.053), due partly to greater active withdrawal in the intervention group (3.8% c/f 2.0%), and partly because the intervention group were harder to find.
In no case did those who withdrew ask us to delete all data.
The major outcome measure was self-report of 6 - month sustained abstinence at 12 - month follow-up.
Point prevalence estimates and perspective on change, both at 12 - month follow-up, are also reported.
We report both cases with outcome data and all cases with missing data treated as smokers, the latter being the key outcome.

Reviews confirm the accuracy of self-report, and conclude that biochemical validation of smoking status is unnecessary in trials where there is no strong association between the interviewer and the respondent) and as our interviewees did no more than ask predetermined questions, and were not common for all assessments, we believe it unlikely that any real relationship was formed.
Biochemical verification was not practical because there was no physical contact with participants.
Questionnaire data were automatically saved to an SQL database, and later converted to a format readable for analysis using SPSS for Windows.
Univariate analyses included c 2 tests for comparing groups and t -tests for comparing means.
Analyses are reported using all available data and all-cases (missing cases coded as smokerstreatment failures).
Subsidiary analyses of the relationship between the number of advice letters received and outcomes are also reported for the intervention condition.
Characteristics of the sample are shown in.
Participants were largely in the engaged (42%) and committed (23%) perspectives on change.
Over a quarter of the sample (27%) had already quit at baseline, the majority of these (63%) within the last week.
As can be seen in, there were no significant differences at baseline between the two groups on key variables.
However, there was a non-significant trend for participants in the tailored advice group to report smoking more cigarettes per day on average than the control group ( t (1056) = 1.93, P = 0.054).
The vast majority of smokers (86%) reported at least one quit attempt.

There was no significant difference between groups in the proportion of participants who reported a quit attempt within the year (88% in the intervention group compared with 85% in the control group; c 2 (1) = 0.67, P = 0.415).
No group differences were significant at the p < 0.05 level.
Ron Borland et al. shows outcome data for the 12 - month followup assessment by group.

Two sets of analyses are shown, first using available data only but including cases regardless of exposure to the intervention (intention to treat), and secondly using all cases, where missing data were included as treatment failures (i.e. smokers).

When using available data only, there were significant differences between the intervention and control groups in point prevalence abstinence at 12 - month follow-up, with 42% of participants in the intervention group quit, compared with 34% in the control group ( c 2 (1) = 4.55, P = 0.033).
For 6 - month sustained abstinence, significantly higher cessation rates were found among the intervention group (30%) compared with the control group (17%; c 2 (1) = 18.43, P < 0.001).

After the inclusion of missing data, the outcome of 6 - month sustained abstinence at 12 - month follow-up remained statistically significant, but the point prevalence estimate became non-significant (see).

Twenty percent of all participants allocated to the intervention group achieved 6 - month sustained abstinence, compared with 12% of those allocated to the control group ( c 2 (1) = 12.60, P < 0.001).
The odds ratio (OR) for quitting was 1.82 (1.31 - 2.55).
We did not conduct the parallel analysis for cases with 12 - month data only, as the differential dropout would have inflated the odds ratio inappropriately.
As can be seen from, there were comparable differences in cessation rates for both those smoking and quit at baseline.

Using only cases with outcome data, the rate of 6 - month sustained abstinence at 12 months for those smoking at baseline was 25% for the intervention group, compared with 12% for the control group, c 2 (1) = 15.17, P < 0.001.
Among those quit at baseline, 6 - month sustained abstinence at 12 months was achieved by 42% in the intervention group, compared with 29% in the control group, c 2 (1) = 3.97, P = 0.046.
A similar pattern was found using all cases.
Logistic regression confirmed that there was no significant interaction between smoking status at baseline and group on outcome ( P = 0.36).
We also analysed the data by perspective at follow-up.
There was a significant group difference in perspective on change at 12 - month follow-up ( c 2 (5) = 20.15, P = 0.001).

This difference can be attributed to a higher proportion of participants in the tailored advice group being in the synthesis perspective (i.e. having quit for at least 2 weeks, with strong temptations to smoke occurring less often than daily) at 12 - month follow-up (36% compared with 25% in the control group).
shows perspective on change at 12 - month follow-up by group, broken down by smoking status at baseline.
Among those smoking at baseline (70% of the eligible sample), 29% of those in the intervention group were in the synthesis (SN) perspective at follow-up, compared with 21% in the control group.
The proportion of the sample in synthesis at 12 - month follow-up increased linearly by perspective on change at baseline, providing some support for the model of perspectives.
Among disengaged smokers at baseline, 16% were in synthesis at 12 - month follow-up, compared with 44% of those who were in the consolidation perspective at baseline.
Unfortunately, the data provided little evidence that those receiving the intervention are more likely to remain engaged with quitting.

There was no group difference with respect to the proportion of participants in the disengaged perspective at 12 - month follow-up (39% in the intervention group compared with 38% in the control group; ( c 2 (1) = 0.07, P = 0.795).
We conducted logistic regression to control for any potential effects of gender, age, cigarette consumption, smoking status at baseline, as well as group.
We used sustained abstinence as the outcome and used all cases (missing cases coded as smokers).
Abstinence at 12 - month follow-up was associated with smoking fewer cigarettes at baseline ( P < 0.001) and being older ( P < 0.001).
We found the expected significant effect for smoking status at baseline ( P < 0.001), and the group effect remained ( P < 0.001), indeed the odds ratio increased to 2.16 (1.52 - 3.08).
To assess dose-response effects, we examined the relationship between number of letters received and the outcome of 6 - month sustained abstinence.
Participants received on average 5.7 advice letters (SD 4.6).
Just over half (51%) received fewer than five advice letters, including 12% (60 participants) who received only one letter.
Number of advice letters received was categorized as in.
There was a significant relationship between number of advice letters received and 6 - month sustained abstinence ( c 2 (5) = 33.74, P < 0.001) for those with outcome data (see).
As expected, the relationship between number of advice letters and outcome increased in magnitude when all cases were analysed ( c 2 (5) = 64.56, P < 0.001).

Participants who refused the intervention were significantly more likely to have been quit at baseline than the rest of the sample ( c 2 (5) = 13.28, P = 0.021), accounting partly for their high rate of sustained abstinence.
It is also notable that the peak effectiveness was fora higher number of calls among those not quit at baseline.

The provision of a series of tailored, computer-generated printed advice letters facilitated smoking cessation to a greater degree than provision of one-off standard printed self-help materials alone.

Using a conservative analysis, in which all cases with missing outcome data were coded as smokers at 12 - month follow-up, 20% of participants randomized to receive the intervention achieved stable cessation (defined as abstinence from smoking for at least 6 months) compared with 12% in the control group.

The magnitude of the effect in absolute terms is larger than for other studies, and the odds ratio (1.82 rising to 2.16 after controlling for confounds) is at the higher end of the range from previous studies).
Moreover, the intervention appears to be comparably effective for those who had recently quit on entering the programme as for those who were smoking at baseline.

Regardless of perspective on change at baseline, participants who received the intervention were more likely than those in the control condition to have progressed to the synthesis perspective by 12 - month follow-up.
The effectiveness of the programme for relapse prevention is an important finding and will be discussed further below.

Over half (52%) of those who participated in the intervention received five or more advice letters, indicating that the majority were prepared to continue to engage with the tailored advice programme when followed-up by telephone.
The high level of compliance with the intervention, coupled with the dose-response effects, indicates that the majority of participants benefited from the tailored information.

It is difficult to attribute the effectiveness of the intervention specifically to either the content of the tailored letters or high level of compliance; both are interrelated and may have contributed to successful outcomes.
The results also emphasize the importance of intervening at strategically relevant times, according to individuals' needs.
This is particularly important immediately following a quit attempt, when relapse is most likely.
In the TTM expert system programme, feedback is provided on a 3 - month cycle only.

Viewing stages in terms of smoker perspectives facilitates a tailored schedule of feedback provision, in which more intensive assistance is provided at critical junctures (e.g. during the first week of nicotine withdrawal).

The comparative effectiveness of the programme in helping recent quitters to progress to stable cessation is evidence of the utility of the revisions to the action stage of the TTM used in the programme.
Significant heterogeneity exists within the action stage, having important implications for relapse prevention interventions.
Overall, the data suggest a benefit of the programme in reducing relapse.

This is due probably to reducing relapse during the period that the intervention was received; however, as the study design makes it difficult to assess relapse after the intervention was discontinued, it is not possible to rule out a sustained benefit.

A limitation of this study is that it is somewhat inconclusive whether the effectiveness of the programme should be attributed to its tailored content or to the greater amount of resources provided to those in the intervention group.
Provision of a series of contacts, of itself, is not necessarily useful as found no benefit of a series of contacts provided at 3 - monthly intervals.) have found beneficial effects.
We suspect the reason for the differences relates to the timeliness of the intervention and the content of the material.
These two were confounded in our study, so we cannot say with confidence which was critical.
However, this maybe academic as it is practically difficult to differentiate the two-good information at the wrong time is not useful, nor is poor information when assistance is needed.
Further, as a reviewer of this manuscript noted, the assessments themselves may have had an impact independent of the advice generated from them.
We can only conclude that the intervention package was effective.
In conclusion, this trial demonstrates the effectiveness of this multiple contact computer-tailored intervention for assisting cessation, particularly by reducing relapse rates.
